text: A dishevelled WOMAN in a business suit (27) runs down a l highway in Texas hill country, moving desperately through the thick morning fog. She's carrying a VHS cassette. The sounds of her breathing and SHOES HITTING the PAVEMENT EC into the mist. She runs, and runs. She slows, out-of-strength, looks up and down the highway Both in front and behind, it leads straight into the mist tunnel of fog. She stumbles on, a final effort. She runs. Sees something. Stops cold.
A clock on the wall: 6:11. Beneath the clock a simple banner reads "DeathWatch Austi
It's probably been about seven  minutes...

The office is small, cheaply furnished. One wall is fille with neat rows of 8x10's of death row inmates. About 30 percent have red crosses over their faces. Five people wait in tense silence. A SKINNY COLLEGE GUY w a mullet and pinch of Skoal in his mouth looks at a compu screen. A co-ed cuddles a Styrofoam cup of coffee, sobs  quietly. A matronly woman sits quietly at a desk holding phone to one ear. The clock's minute hand changes from :11 to :12. CONSTANCE HARRAWAY (36), bookish, sits beside DAVID GALE  (31). He wears a blue Yale sweatshirt. They both stare at nothing. She bites her lip.
Okay. Okay. We've got pronouncement.  6:12. Roughly eight minutes. (a beat as he records  the time) Number 36 this year for the Great  State of Texas.
They all exchange looks: they've lost. David stands.
David, don't start throwing things.
A PHONE RINGS. David controls himself.
I'm going home. Let's do the press  fax tomorrow.
Another PHONE RINGS. Constance stands.
Go. I'll do it.
He nods to her, exits. She walks to the photo wall. With a red magic marker she  marks a cross over the photo of a Hispanic male. The wall clock reads 6:13.

location: PARKING LOT IN FRONT OF OFFICE

text: The office is in a largely abandoned mini-mall. It's goin to be a clear summer day. David hurries through the empty parking lot to Volvo station wagon. As the car exits the lot, we see the Austin skyline with capitol building in the distance.
David drinks from a travel cup as he drives, windows down
David stops at a red light beside a squad car with one co inside. The cop gives him a cursory glance.
He stares at the cop. The cop looks neutrally ahead; behi him the buckle of his seat belt shoulder strap catches th reflection of the rising sun.
He stares, then:
Hey!
The cop ignores him.
Yo! Officer!
The cop looks over; his face says he expects a confrontat David points to the seat belt buckle.
Your seatbelt.
The cop nods, weary, embarrassed. He reaches back for the belt. David takes a sip and drives on.
Court TV reporter, Roberts, stands in front of the Suprem Court.
The high court also refused to stay  Friday's execution of former  philosophy professor, David Gale.
(with her mouth full) Christ doin' Karaoke.

head_text.subj: PULL BACK TO REVEAL WE ARE IN

text: KRUGER (47) watches with a leg up on her messy desk, eati low-fat tortilla chips and massaging a knee with an elect massager. A name plate on her desk reads "Barbara D. Krug Crime and Courts Editor." News magazine covers are on the walls. Kruger is black, short, overweight, wears an old  jogging suit and new oversized athletic shoes. She has ha frame granny glasses on a cord around her neck.
Gale had sought a review of his 1993  conviction for the rape and murder  of University of Texas colleague,  Constance Harraway.
Kruger reaches for a phone, hits four numbers, takes a ch
A book-jacket photo of Constance.
Defense lawyers had hoped to argue  that Gale's former activism against  capital punishment unduly  prejudiced...
She waits impatiently, munching, swallowing.
...the Texas judicial system. Citing  'discriminating purpose' --
(into the phone) Hey, they're not gonna stay Gale.  It's on Court TV right now, listen.
She holds the phone out in the direction of the TV, uses opportunity to eat another chip.
We see old footage of David on a TV talk show.
...clear political gain in executing  its leading opponent of the death  penalty...
(into the phone,  swallowing) So, what's it gonna be? Belyeu said  to call after the decision... No,  they said only Bitsey.
(in b.g.) ...Further failed to consider that  the victim was herself an abolitionist  activist...
It means only Bitsey. Bill, I don't  get to make the rules, I'm a fat  black woman.
Bitsey Bloom (The runner from the opening) enters. She we as always, a tailored suit.
(into the phone) ...What we need is to put her on a  plane to Houston.
Gale's going down.
Kruger shushes her with a we-know-already gesture.
(into the phone) Why do you always get lordosis around  legal? She's here.
She puts him on SPEAKER, and reaches for a chip.
(to the phone) Hi. What's lordosis?
Female ape's posture when preparing  for intercourse. Hello, Bitsey.
Bitsey shoots Kruger a look, mouths "you're sick."
Look, kids, setting aside the cost  issue, though half-a-million dollars  for three two hour interviews is not  only illegal it's obscen--
Market value. Guy's never talked.
That aside, I, we are still  uncomfortable with the arrangement.
Meaning?
Meaning you've just spent a very  public seven days in jail for a very  public contempt of court citation.
Protecting sources, even kiddie porn  scumbags, is magazine policy.

And I, we continue to appreciate  your decision. We're just concerned.  A rapist slash murderer, five days  before he's executed, demands a  reporter known for protecting sexual  deviants. A reporter who is also a  very attractive woman --
Bitsey and Kruger moan in unison.
This is disparate treatment.
I could go if I were an ugly blabby  guy?
There's an agenda issue here which  would be diffused with an older  male...
I hear lawyers gleefully saying the  words Bloom vs. News Magazine Inc.
'Well, Your Honor, I started to notice  that my assignments were evaluated  on the basis of my sex.'
You've gotta let her go now.
That's not quite what I meant.
He's gotta let you go.
'Certain references were made -- '
(interrupting) All right. All right. Enough. The  intern is with you at all times?
Bitsey vehemently shakes her head "no" to this idea.
Yes. I, we are hanging up. 'Bye.
Kruger hangs up the phone before he can respond.
I'm not baby-sitting.
Kruger reaches for a chip.

ZACK (boyish, 24) sits in the passenger seat, smoking and looking at a case file in his lap. He holds the cigarette just outside the slightly open window. Zack has a bohemia grunge thing going -- long hair, ultra-hip glasses. As Bi drives, she keeps looking down at the dash's instrument p We hear strained patience in her voice.
Gale was seen leaving the house.
The car's lights move past a sign: "Huntsville 27 Miles."
His sperm was inside her.
His prints were all over the kitchen,  including one on the bag.
Zack has a police photo: a woman naked on a kitchen floor hands handcuffed behind her. Over her head is an opaque w plastic bag, sealed around the neck with duct tape.
Half-a-thumb print.
Okay, half-a-thumb print.
Could have touched it before it was  a murder weapon.
Do you fondle your friends' garbage  bags?
Yeah, I get very touchy around  household plastics. 'Hello, everybody --  ooooh, Tupperware.' Chill. I'm just  saying the bag could have been out  on the counter or something.
She looks at him a beat.
Hey, Zack?
Yeah.
He did it.
But the murder's way too fucking  clumsy. And this guy's a major  intellectual. Top of his Yale class,  a Rhodes gig, tenured at 27, two  books. He's an academic stud.
And, empirically speaking, a  psychotic.
Zack picks up another file photo: Christmas shot of the G family: David (31), his wife (Sharon, beautiful, 29), and son (Chase, 6).
Look at his wife, she's a regular  Grace Kelly. Old money svelte. Father  was Ambassador to Spain --
(looking at the car's  instrument panel) Shit! The light's on again.
is on.
Ignore it. It's a rental.
Thanks, Zack. Do you smell anything?
No. Besides the guy's a flaming  liberal.
Bitsey keeps looking down at the light.
A person's politics has nothing to  do with their propensity to commit  crime. (beat) Aren't we supposed to smell it if  it's overheating?
Wrong, seventy-three percent of all  serial killers vote republican.
Throw the cigarette out so we can  smell.
Zack reaches for the car ashtray.
No! You'll stink up the car. Throw  it out!
I'm not gonna fucking pollute.
Zack!
Zack pinches the cherry off, lets it drop out the window. He shows her the filter, animatedly puts in the ash tray. She gives him a look. They ride a beat in silence. Bitsey sniffs.
We better pull off. Shit, this is so  irritating.
How far to Huntsville?
Look.
She points to an approaching rest area exit sign. They sh a glance, then a laugh. Zack affects an evil, maniacal ca
('Hard Copy'  announcer's voice) 'NEWS Magazine reporters Bitsy Bloom  and Zack Stemmons entered the rest  area with car trouble...
The car exits for the rest area.
Little did they know their troubles  were just beginning.
Zack mimics the OPENING MUSIC to "Dark Shadows."
Well lit and empty. The rental car is parked with the hoo up. They stand looking at the radiator.
Is it hot?
He puts his hand on it.
Oww! Jesus, yes. Isn't it always?
Bitsey shrugs.
So what do I do?
I don't know, something male.
Zack animatedly adjusts his balls, spits.
Now what?
Bitsey's not paying attention. She's watching headlights  coming toward them.
Company.
I hope whoever it is never saw  Deliverance.
A late model pickup pulls up behind them. They shade thei eyes from its headlights. The lights go off. An OLDER COW (mid-60's, Stetson, lizard skin boots) steps out.
You folks need some help?
Actually yes.
The motel lies adjacent to Interstate 45 and a Kettle  restaurant. The rental car pulls up to the reception buil
The rental car is parked in front. The morning is overcas it's sprinkling. Bitsey emerges from one of the rooms on second floor carrying an umbrella.
Bitsey enters and sees Zack in a booth, smoking and readi The hyper-smiley TEENAGE HOSTESS approaches her.
How are you this morning?
Bitsey ignores her, takes a menu without comment. She goe and sits across from Zack; he's reading Dialogical Exhaus by David Gale.
Little early, isn't it?
The non-smoking section's over there.
I meant the book.
Oh.
Bitsey opens the menu; he puts the book down.
What time is it?
9:15. The waitress says the Ellis  Unit is about fifteen minutes out of  town, so we've got like five and  half hours. I --
Never eat where the menus have  pictures of the food.
I was thinking we should drive to  Austin, check out the crime scene.  Could be some story stuff for us.
(without looking up) First, this isn't a story. It's an  interview. We come, I listen, you  watch, we go home. Second, there is  no 'us' in the assignment.
Okay, what do I watch you do for the  next five hours?
(closing the menu) Drive around looking for decent  restaurant.
You know, your reputation as Siberian- Female-Dog-Person doesn't do you  justice.
She's unsure how to interpret his comment. He smiles.
My reputation got us invited here. I  play by the rules. It's called  objectivity.
They stare at each other. Zack picks up his book, starts read, affects a shiver.
Drizzle. The prison and adjacent parking lot can be seen few hundred yards down the road. In front of the guardhou is a sign: "TDC Ellis Unit. All visitors must report."
The rental car ENTERS the FRAME, brakes briefly for the e guardhouse, and moves on toward the prison.
Bitsey and Zack get out of their car. She has an umbrella
So where do we report?

Three razor wire fences surround the prison. Guard towers rise at the corners. Outside the fence sits a small build with a sign: "REPORT HERE." Bitsey makes a there-you-have-it face. They move toward t building. Someone hawks. They look over. Within the fence, a skinny Hispanic inmate (50's) spits. He's hunched in the rain th yards away. He watches them neutrally. CAMERA TRACKS Bitsey and Zack as they walk nervously past series of kennel-like pens that run along a long building Inmates watch them pass: A smoking, tattooed white male ( stands by his door. A muscular black man (30's) with a Mu skullcap speaks quietly to the forty-something redneck be him. A paunchy Hispanic (20's) with a shaved head sits ba against the building, making clicking sounds. A skinny wh guy with his shirt off tosses a tennis ball against the  building. At the closest end of the last pen, a gang-bang (20's) watches as he stands with his fingers clutching th chain-link above his head. Rain runs down his face.
As Bitsey and Zack enter, a clean-cut man in his forties on the phone (DUKE GROVER). He waves them in and holds up wait-just-a-second finger.
Well, I don't rightly know one  fraternity from another. But if we  catch any those boys out here again,  we're gonna Arrest and Prosecute...  You do that, Susan... Bye now.

The office has cheap wood paneling and a tired shag carpe A portrait of GOVERNOR HARDIN (female, mid-50's) is on th wall, a large aerial photograph of the prison on the othe At a desk sits a WOMAN WITH TEXAS HAIR (40's). Grover hangs up.
(to the Woman) Thank you, Margie. (turning to Bitsey  and Zack) Correspondents Bloom and Stevens I  presume.
Yes, hello.
They shake hands.
Stemmons.
Stemmons. Sorry, won't happen again.  I'm Duke Grover, T.D.C. community  relations.
Grover's demeanor suggests a successful Little League coa his suit suggests J.C. Penny. He speaks quickly.
He's usually real good with names.
(to Bitsey) And these days I always like to ask,  now do you prefer Miss, Mrs. or Ms.?
Bitsey.
Bitsey it is. Margie, I'm stealin'  your umbrella.
Okey dokey.
Bitsey and Grover walk beneath their umbrellas toward the Unit gate -- Grover walks as fast as he talks. Zack follo turns his collar up.
Bitsey, you ever been in a prison?
Yes.
Zack smiles to himself.
On death row?
No.
Well, we house 422 inmates here.  Average stay with us is nine years.  Some get commuted, move on, most get  killed. It'll put you off your supper,  but then it's supposed to.
The unit fence gate parts as they enter. The older gate g nods as they pass.

(to the guard) Afternoon, Earl. (back to her) We've got three concerns here: safety,  safety and safety. The visitation  area is entirely secure -- we just  ask you don't touch the glass. Windex  gets expensive.
They come to the door of the entrance area.
Rules say seven days prior to  execution inmates must be interviewed  in a cage.
The DOOR BUZZES, Grover opens it.
The lobby has institutional chairs and few vending machin To one side is a guard's counter and a walk through metal detector. They enter and make their way toward the counte
This changes for no man. You're not  carryin' a weapon are you?
No.
Mr. Stemmons, you packin'?
No, sir.
They arrive at the counter. Behind it are two GUARDS, one male, one female.
(to the guards) Clarence. Karla. New York guests for  Mr. Gale.
May I see your purse, ma'am.
(to Bitsey, indicating  the metal detector) Go on and walk through.
Grover keeps talking as he walks around the detector and  waits for her.

Now, should any kinda of  unpleasantness occur in the visitation  area, we ask that you stay put. Come  on through, Mr. Stemmons. And please  follow the instructions of these  fine correctional officers should  they see fit to give you any.
(handing her the purse) Here you go, ma'am.
He leads them down the hall.
Anythin' you say can be overheard.
And any discussion of criminal activity on your part is  admissible. Not plannin' a jailbreak are you, Bitsey?
The door guard gets up from his small table and opens the door for them.
Here we are.

The visitation hall has the linoleum-and-fluorescent feel an empty school cafeteria. It is seamlessly intersected b curved wall of sheer glass. Across the hall a guard's boo is built into the concrete wall; the two guards inside lo like they are in a sound booth. Every fifteen feet, the glass has small sound holes. On t visitors' side, chairs (with lap desks) cluster at each  section. Just getting up from a chair in the hall's cente is a big man wearing an expensive suit and black cowboy b This is David's lawyer, BENJAMIN BELYEU (late 30's). On the prisoner's side of the glass, a row of ten chairs  trace the outline of its curve. Above each chair a microp hangs from the ceiling. The center chair is in a stainles steel cage. Inside sits David Gale.
(calling out to Belyeu) All yours, Mr. Belyeu. (to Bitsey and Zack) You folks have safe visit now.
Thank you.
He exits as Bitsey and Zack make their way toward Belyeu David; it's a walk of about twenty-five feet. Belyeu's voice is a thick combination of Cajun and Harvar Yard.
Miss Bloom?
Yes.
Belyeu speaks as slowly as Grover did quickly. David stan up politely in his cage -- he's too tall and has to hunch
Did that P.R. man validate your  parkin'?
He said the gift shop could do it.
Belyeu laughs, smiles pure Old New Orleans charm.
(to David) She's a smart one.
Belyeu takes a few steps toward them, extends his hand.
Benjamin Belyeu, Mr. Gale's attorney.
This is Zack.
Pleasure. (turning) And this is the man of the hour.
They move toward David. A SPEAKER-SYSTEM LOUDLY (really  loudly) interrupts:
Sit down, Gale.
All wince. David sits, smiles, a bit embarrassed.
Hello.
Hello.
Hi.
Now, why can't they turn that thing  down?
(to the microphone  above him) My lawyer respectfully suggests you  adjust the speaker-system volume.
A beat. They all look over at the guard's booth. One of t guards makes a get-on-with-your-business gesture.
They're practicing being cruel and  unusual.
Mrs. Bloom, I'm sure you're a bitin'  at the bit.
Belyeu collects papers from the chair he was using and st to stuff them into his antique carpetbag.

Now, it is our understanding that  you are to have three two-hour  sessions. Today, tomorrow and  Thursday, all at three in the P.M.  I'm sorry we can't afford you more  time, but contrary to popular rumor  we have not yet begun to fight.  Furthermore, it's our understanding  that you will do this with no  recording equipment of any kind. (to David) You have my Gregg book?
I need it for Billy's appeal.

(to Bitsey) My client's got a ten pound bass on  the line and he's worried about  baitin' his neighbor's hook. (takes out his planner) Now, I have some papers for which I  need your Jo Ann Hancock. (handing her a business  card) Come by my Austin office at your  earliest convenience. Thursday  mornin', say.
Bitsey's confused. Belyeu just smiles at her, then looks at the microphone. She understands, nods.
Fine, till Thursday then.
Belyeu picks up his bag. He and Zack start the hike to th door. Belyeu turns, walks backwards.
Good luck, Miss Bloom. (to David) I'll come by later. We can play a  game of hangman, take up smokin'.
David waves "get lost." Belyeu turns.
Bye, ya' all.
They watch him walk away. Bitsey turns to David. He's loo at the floor, caught in a thought.
So...
Sorry. Have a seat.
She does so. David smiles at her, he has a beautiful smil sincere, charming, vaguely devilish.
He's a character.
Yeah, known Benny most my life. Met  the summer after 4th grade, spent  the day burning ants with his dad's  magnifying glass. We called it playing  'Execution.'
David looks at her a beat, lets the irony of this sit in air. Uncomfortable, Bitsey starts to look in her purse.
Since I grew up in foster homes,  he's become the only family I have.
Where's your ex-wife?
Bitsey takes a pad out of her purse, looks for a pen.
We agreed minimal contact would be  easier. Please don't mention her, or  my son.
All right. Anything else, just clearly  say, 'off the record.' I'll take it  to my grave. But then you know that  about me. Otherwise I wouldn't be  here.
David smiles, nods.
(referring to the pen) Is this recording equipment?
He shrugs.
How should we start?
I'd say you're a man with a story to  tell, Mr. Gale. You chose the  magazine, the format. You chose me.
She sits with pen on paper, poised for dictation.
Go.
David looks at her a long beat, then gives her the smile.
CAMERA starts TO ROTATE and ROLLS THROUGHOUT until the LA SHOT COMES TO REST UPRIGHT.
Belyeu gets in his Cadillac in the wet Ellis Unit parking lot.
from the air.
SEXY FEMALE GRAD STUDENT (over-dressed in a mini-skirt an heels) moves hurriedly through the University of Texas (U campus.
attending class in an U.T. lecture hall -- they are laugh as David entertains from a mike at the podium.

Thirty animated students (circa 1992) are listening to Da lecture. He's younger (31), vibrant -- looks like a grad  student himself. On the white board behind him are phrase "Lucan," "objet petit a," "Fantasy Theory."

Think. What do you fantasize about?  World peace? (as no one responds) Thought so. (light laughter) Money-Fame-Ferrari? (as some guys applaud  loudly; others then  boo them) A Pulitzer? Nobel? M.T.V. Music Award? (applause) A genius hunk -- ostensibly bad but  secretly simmering with noble  passions, and willing to sleep on  the wet spot?
As women applaud...
(yells) I'll take two!
Laughter.
A Victoria's Secret model -- just  slumming between law school and  running her family's Vastly Endowed  Foundation for Tragically Sad-Eyed  Children?
The crowd laughs, David changes tone.

Okay, good, you see Lucan's point.  Fantasies must be unrealistic. The  minute you get something, you don't,  you can't, want it anymore. To exist,  desire needs absent objects. So desire  supports itself with crazy  fantasies...
The over-dressed Sexy Grad Student enters loudly from a s door, out-of-breath and discombobulated. The crowd laughs the timing. David pauses.
Sorry.
He animatedly gestures to the seats, waits a beat as she  moves towards them.
This is what Pascal means when he  says the only time we're truly happy  is when day-dreaming about future  happiness.
The Sexy Student sits, adjusts herself.
Or why we say, 'The hunt is sweeter  than the kill' or 'Be careful what  you wish for.'
A guy behind the Sexy Student taps her on the shoulder, s turns and he hands her letter from the registrar's office It's from a girl friend two rows back. The girlfriend mou "It came today?"
Not because you'll get it, but because  you're doomed not to want it if you  do. Think about it next time you're  at a wedding.
Laughter. The Sexy Student turns back around, throws the  letter in a book.

Students pour out of the double doors leading from David' class. The hall is crowded. Standing waiting for him agai the wall is Constance (glasses, granola clothes). She's looking at a document, holds a file.
The students are leaving. David is quickly erasing the wh board. The Sexy Student approaches him (her name is Berli
Sorry about being late. There was,  you know, a thing.
There usually is, Berlin.
Look, I know I'm not doing well.
He turns, nods, takes his books and papers from the podiu
And to torture a cliche, I'd do  anything to pass.
He looks at her a beat, starts to walk toward the door.
Anything, Professor Gale.
He stops, turns.
Anything, huh?
(suggestively) Anything.
(the smile) Anything?
She affects a solicitous shyness -- then goes all sex.
Any thing.
He checks the room, then comes over to her, close.
Tell you what, I'll give you good  grade, a really good grade, if you  will... (leans down to her  ear, whispers  sensually) ...study.
He smiles, turns, walks away. As she watches, anger build
David comes out the room. Constance sees him, hurries to  him. She's excited, and speaks now -- as always -- with  absolute authority. They talk as they walk down the crowd hall.
David!
Hey.
The T.A. finished transcribing the  Governor's radio and TV comments.  Listen: 'I hate killing, that's why  I'm willing to kill to stop it.' The  woman breathes in soundbites.
She hands him a copy.
(pretends to read a  quote) 'Yes, Virginia, the people of this  State have overwhelmingly affirmed  the reality of Santa.'
You might can use some of her pre- centrist stuff.
Tell me again why you aren't doing  the debate.
Telegenics. You have a cuter butt.
I hadn't noticed.
I know.
That's not what I meant.
David and Constance exit the building into the sun.
She's gonna do the whole mother thing.  She empathizes with you completely,  but experience has given her the  courage to take the tougher road, ta- da, ta-da. Keep it rational. And  flirt politely.
'Governor, you bat a lovely lash for  a woman who executed thirty eight  last year.'
They've come to a sidewalk junction, stop.
And watch your ego. Don't come across  as one of those I-hate-authority- because-nobody-in-charge-reads-the- New Yorker types.
Anything else?
Yeah, don't fall into one of your  brooding silences. Oh, I'm getting  new federal stats from Amnesty  tonight.
I'm going to Greer's party. Fax them  to Sharon's number at the house.
She looks at him sternly over the top of her glasses.
If you have a hang-over tomorrow --
(hangs up, walking  away) Apropos playing Mother.
(calling after him) Ten o'clock! (beat) Bright-eyed and bushy tailed!

The house is an immaculately restored two-story Victorian far better than what a university professor can afford. The grounds are perfect. David's Volvo is in the driveway his wife's new Laredo beside it. On the street out front  sits a new VW Beetle.

David's son -- CHASE -- sits in bed holding a stuffed she in the air. David turns off the light in the adjacent  bathroom, comes in holding his son's jeans and shoes. Dav wears a t-shirt which says "Evil-Doer & Curious Person." room is over-decorated with boy stuff.
Did you mark your calendar?
(looking up at it) Yep.

hangs above the bed, opened to the month of March. It has felt-tipped pen hanging from a piece of string taped to i Ten frowny faces cover ten consecutive days, then there a three empty days before a large smiley face awaits on the fourth. The frowny faces are in a kid's hand, the smiley  face in an adult's.
(counting on his  fingers) Only... three more Spain days.
David puts the jeans and shoes away.
Only three. That's great, huh?
David comes and sits beside his son. Points to an African statue (a man holding a spear) on the bedside table.
What's he doing in here?
Mommy said I could. Just till she  gets back. (touching the spear) That's a special-duper monster laser  knife.
Where's your laser gun?
Chase reaches under the sheets, searches, finally pulls o a laser pointer.
Here.
He "shoots" some toys in the corner with the red laser do
Tussshh, tusssshh, tussshh. I never  shoot them in the eyes, Daddy.
That's 'cause you're a special-duper- super-quadruper boy. Who's now going  to sleep.
He tucks his son in.
Who loves you?
Chase giggles, points at his dad, then pokes his nose.
Ooooh. (kissing him) Good night, son.
(holding up his stuffed  sheep) Do Cloud Dog.
(kissing the sheep) Good night, Cloud Dog.

Obsessively cool, full of designer furniture and rough  fabrics. The art is mostly contemporary and conspicuously lit -- a Damien Hirst piece sits in one corner. A few Afr antiquities are scattered throughout. A BABYSITTER sits on the couch reading a school textbook, holding lip gloss and absentmindedly applying it as she r David passes on his way to the door.
Back before midnight.
It's cool, Mr. Gale. (calling after him) Don't do anything I wouldn't.
Rest assured.
He exits. When she hears the DOOR CLOSE, the Babysitter  reaches for the TV remote.

The duplex is upscale, two-story with a vaulted ceiling. Scattered about are forty party-goers, mostly grad studen Some spill out onto the back patio and around the pool.  Everyone has a t-shirt with a philosophic idea ("Yawnic," "Mad, Bad and Dangerous to Know," "[Philosophic t-shirt]" LEONARD COHEN MUSIC PLAYS.
GREER (late 20s, Persian, "Host" t-shirt) escorts David i the living room.
The guy's the Immanuel Kant of the  N.F.L. Consistent, accurate,  effective, and boring, boring, boring.
Greer leaves him at the sofa where an OLDER PROFESSOR (60 homemade t-shirt -- "Pre-Socratic" -- over his shirt and  tie) stands speaking with ROSS (late 40s, "Homosexualist" shirt).
Meinen Herren.
(has an Oxford accent) Hello, David.
Professor Gale. Where's your better  half?
Spain.
Again? (a beat) Well, I was just off for air.
